div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Bold Expressions from a Northern Clergyman.
div3.p:
At a recent meeting of the Democratic Club of Philadelphia, the Rev. G. C. Burr, formerly editor of the New York Daily News, was one of the speakers, and denounced the Administration of Lincoln in the most bitter terms.
He said it was a drunken Administration, besotted with its isolation of the Constitution, and had never had one honest pulsation for the good of the country.
It was a set of reseals.
He had lately been to Washington and his soul was filled with shame when he saw the streets of that city filled with lunatics and persons looking as if they had come from Bediam or some Free-Love association.
The members of the Administration, the speaker said, were not fit to be boot-blacks for his honorable auditors.
[Applause] Abraham Lincoln is a greater traitor than Jefferson Davis.
What has Jeff Davis done?
He has merely infringed upon our territorial jurisdiction; he has not struck at the Constitution.

On State rights, Burr discoursed at length.
He believed that we would have to come back to the good old doctrine of State-rights to save the Republic, and said that the United States have no rights, and were marely rested on the solid basis of State-rights.
Suppose that a State should refuse to elect a Senator or a Representative, where would your United States be?
Congress is nothing but the representative of the States, and this is the only doctrine that can save us. What we want is pluck.
"No we don't," interposed a voice. "We want money."

"Yes, sir," continued the speaker.
We want muscle.
Carry the pluck which you have displayed this evening with you into the street.
If you do so, the Provost Marshal of this city will be more afraid of being ridden suddenly on a rail than you will be of any injury which he can do to your constitutional liberties." [Applause, and, in loud tones, "we will, we will"] After the applause had subsided, the speaker said, "When the soul of this Government is dead, I for one, care not what becomes of its body." [Applause] "If a plot which is now proposed should succeed, that one of our soldiers should go to Richmond and assassinate Jefferson Davis and bring back his head, he hoped it would be put on Abe Line ln's shoulders."--[Loud and long continued cheering] Mr. Burr reiterated that Mr. Lincoln was a greater traitor than Jeff Davis, and if his Abolition policy was permitted to go on, he (Mr. B.) maintained that Jefferson Davis was fighting for liberties in the North, as well as those of his fellow citizens in the South.
Why not stop this war now? --Why, my friends, you will ask, "How can we do so without disgrace?" Why, if you are disgraced now, what will your dishonor amount to six months hence, if you go on making dead men and public debt?
If this Abolition programme was to be carried out, and negroes were to be put in our forts as garrison troops, he, as a peace man, thought it would be his time to turn soldier.
He contemplated the new compromise line with pleasure.
It would run East of New Jersey, and would therefore include that State and Pennsylvania.
As for New England, he cared very little whether it came in or not. These States might be tolerated in the new Union as a sort of ulcer which could not be taken out until it was perfectly ripe.
The Baltimore Republican, in commenting on Napoleon's letter to Gen. Forey, says:

q.p:
"Must we, under the lead of a junta of visionary madmen, still imitate the dog in the fable, and grasping at the shadow lose the substance?
There is but one of two courses left for the Government to pursue, in order to avoid the very worst future consequences of these designs of the French Emperor.
It will either be compelled to accept a war with France, whilst the South is still in arms or by a speedy recognition of the seceded States, at once defeat the schemes of Napoleon and put an end to the civil war. We do not know whether this will be considered 'treason' by the powers that be, but is our honest conviction that it is the only course by which, not only this country, but the continent, will be saved from complications with the diplomacy and powers of Europe."

div4.head: Romance and Reality of the War.
div4.p: The Holly Springs correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat narrates the experience of a cotton buyer among the Mississippi guerrillas, as follows:

The experience of a Mr. Cones, who was "gobbled," as it is now yclept, near LaGrange, five or six weeks ago, was relieved by some flashes of humor which may be an apology for the very emphatic language which was used by the actors.

Cones, in company with two or three other buyers, had bought some cotton out at Moscow, twelve miles from LaGrange, just before our army marched from the latter place, and as Gen Quinby's division had just removed from there, they thought the sooner they got the cotton into LaGrange the better; consequently four of them, besides the drivers of the teams, started out after it. Cones was the only one of the four who was not armed, and was not on horseback, he riding in one of the wagons.
They succeeded in getting the cotton and hurried back until they came in sight of the Union pickets at LaGrange, and then Conts's three friends, thinking the teams were out of danger, left him and rode on into town.

Only two or three minutes after they had left, and as the wagons went down into a hollow, out of sight of the picket guards five guerillas dashed out of the woods and were alongside in an instant.
Halt! Every one of the teams halted as though they had run against a stone wall.
The next instant the muzzle of a revolver was at the ear of every one of them, Cones included, who was riding on the cotton.
"Are you armed?" asked the guerilla who held his pistol at Cones's head.
"No, sir."
"Then get down and unhitch them mules, and turn 'em round d — d quick!"
It was done in the time specified.

Guerilla--"Have you a match?
I want to touch off this cotton."
Cones--"No, sir. I am glad to say I haven't."
Guerilla--"Then git onto that mule quick!"
In an instant Cones was mounted on what he says was "a wonderful sharp-backed mule."

Guerilla giving the mule a terrific slash with the wagon whip, "Now, d — n you, lick them mules up!
Make 'em go!
Give em thunder!"

And away they went at a pace, which to Cones, on his razor back mule he thought must split him in two before many miles, three guerilla behind lashing the mule at every jump.
Five miles or more they went at this pace, and not another word had been spoken by any one, when they turned out of the main road into an old and unfrequented road, that wound its zigzags through one of the densely wooded creek bottoms. "Halt!" said the guerilla, and he who gave the command commenced hurriedly to relieve himself of some of his accoutrements, as though he was about to go to work in earnest at some devilish deed.
The place was lonely and fitting to such murderous intents, and Cones says he felt a cold sort of children down the full length of even his long legs.

Guerilla--(drawing the cork of his canteen)--"You look like a pretty d — d good feller.
Let's taste a drink; and for fear you might think its dizen.
I'll drink first!"

And suiting the action to his words, he placed the canteen to his lips, and turned his face up in the position of one making astronomical observations.
After a long pull, he passed the canteen over to Cones, who thought it "mightn't be dizen," and imbibed.

Guerilla--"Now, d — n you lick up them mules; give 'em thunder!
Hurry up! "
And each injunction be emphasized on the rear of the flying mules with his whip.

They bivouacked in a thicket that night, but early next morning began their journey at the same pace, and toward evening of that day they galloped into a rude looking camp, which turned out to be the next of Richardson and his guerilla band within a few miles of Fort Pillow.
In a few minutes Cones was marched up before Col. Richardson.
After a number of questions, as to what was his business, whether he had not served against the Confederate States, etc., Richardson said:
At the mention of parole the guerilla who had been the most prominent in the capture, and had invited Cones to drink, begun to remonstrate.
Guerilla--"Why, Colonel, you atu't a goin' to parole that d — d cotton buyer, are you?"
Richardson--"Well, I've got to parole him or shoot him; and (turning to Cones inquiringly,) you'd rather be paroled than shot, hadn't you?"
Cones--"Yes, d — d if I hadn't; but I don't want to take another such a ride on that mule."

The written, and much to his seventh without being sold of his money and watch, he was told that he at Hocerty to walk back to La Grange forty miles. In an hour afterwards he started, and soon after leaving the camp he was startled by the command " !"--He halted, and out stepped the guerilla who had been most prominent in his capture, and who had gone away sulky because the Colonel would not shoot" that d — d cotton buyer," instead of paroling him.

Cones was unarmed, and began to have serious apprehensions of what was to follow, when the guerilla said: "Old seller, let's take a drink?"--Cones's heart felt lighter immediately.
So did the canteen.

div4.head: "Free Americans of African descent" in Arkansas.
div4.p: Since the 1st of January the negroes in some portions of Arkansas are having a hard time of it. The Helena (Ark.) correspondent of the Chicago Times gives the following account of one of the many similar scene occurring in the Federal camps:

J. S. Pillow, brother of the rebel General, who has a beautiful plantation a few miles from Helena, and who was worth half a million of dollars previous to the war, came into camp, through the lines, with one hundred and eighty three negroes, of both sexes and of all ages.
At the head of his servants, who followed in single file, he walked to the Colonels headquarter, where the following conversation took place:
"Good morning, sir"
"Good morning, sir."
"Where is the commandant of the peat?"
"Before you, sir."

"Well, Colonel here is my small change, in the shape of free American citizens, of African descent, which I deliver over to you. Here is a correct list of their names, ages, sexes, and occupations.
Please send them on to the President, with my compliments and say to him that if he wishes anything else under my roof, on my grounds, or in my pockets, all he has to do is to ask and receive"
"Mr. Pillow, I cannot receive these people I have no food for them — have nothing for them to do — have not food enough for our soldiers, hardly."

"And I cannot use them.
I had bacon to keep them on, but it has been stolen.
I had corn, but it has been gabbed.
Now, I have nothing for them to eat, and as Lincoln has turned this army into a nigger boarding house, you will please seat these people at your table."
"But I have no such power."

"Then give them work.
If you fail to manage them, I will teach you. The art can be learned in about thirty years."
"I have nothing for them to do."

"Nor have I.
You will not see them starve, I hope.
You have surely some use for them.
Nearly all trades are here represented among the men.--The women you can find use for somewhere."
"Well, I can't take them."

"My God!
What will they live on?
Can you sell me corn and bacon?
They will starve unless you do!"
"No, I cannot."
"And you cannot keep them!"
'No.'
"Well, God only knows what will become of them."

At the head of his old servants he left, and the free people followed him back, crying and wondering what next will come in their behalf.
The poor creatures come into camp steal provisions, etc., are kicked and cuffed about by all hands, and at times most unmercifully pounded by some soldier who will not stand their "sass." The only idea ninety- five of every hundred of slaves have of freedom, is case, freedom from labor, their, and last.

It is stated that the citizens of Baltimore having refused to give employment to the refugee negroes, they are kept in camp at Bladensburg, where they are dying at the rate of twenty or thirty per day.

div4.head: An interesting letter — the private opinion of a Yankee Naval officer.
div4.p:
Among the papers found on board the Yankee gunboat Issac P. Smith, at the time of her capture in Stono River, was a long private letter from one of the officers of the boat.
The letter is in the form of a journal, and though unfinished, unsigned, and without address, is evidently written by Lieut. T. S. Conover, who commanded the Smith.
We make an extract, which is interesting as throwing light upon the private views of an intelligent Yankee officer on the subject of the war. The vessel was captured on the afternoon of Friday, January 30, but the letter was closed only the night before:

Tuesday Evening, January 27th.--A misty, damp, and unpleasant day, my dear — in which we have done nothing, and seen, if possible less.
Tomorrow, if it is a good day, and nothing prevents, I shall probably take a look up one of the rivers.--These large planters along the coast, and those near the Mississippi, are the ones who have suffered most in the war, I expect.
All along here, for miles, are plantations entirely deserted, with houses, fences, and everything going to ruin.
In going up the Kiawah river on Saturday, we passed one which we had not seen before, and which had quite the air of an old English castle built of wood.--Around it were all sorts of out-buildings and slave quarters, and the whole place had the air of an establishments kept up upon a large scale.
But I suppose it was left soon after the war broke out, and now it is going to deney very rapidly.
I must say that I can't wonder at the bitter feeling of these people.
Think how we would feel, driven away from Amboy, for instance, and with the Alabama lying in the river opposite the house, and ready to throw a shot into it if we made our appearance there!
I am very glad that your father feels so hopeful about matters; but I must say that I cannot see what he founds his hopefulness upon.
To my thinking, we are as far off as over from subduing the rebellion, though we may be nearer the end of it in some way or other.
No one seems to be moving now except the Western forces.
Gen. Rosecrans appears to go ahead and succeed wherever he is placed; so he may have to be tried at last at the head of the Grand Army of the Potomac.

div4.head: A Southern account of the fall of Arkansas Post.
div4.p:
The public has never been satisfied with the vague and meagre reports which have reached us of the surrender of the Post of Arkansas.
The following is a trustworthy account of the disaster, derived from a Southern officer of high rank:

The Post on the Arkansas River, distant from its month some fifty miles by water, and twenty by land, and from Little Rock by land 110 miles, was under the immediate command of Gen. Churchill.
During the last summer and fall some defences were thrown up there, consisting of an embankment surrounded by a ditch, and with such guns as could be procured--one nine inch Dahlgren and two eight-inch Columbians, with a battery of small pieces arranged to resist an attack by land.
This armament, with a corps of about 4 000 men, constituted Gen. Churchill's entire resources for meeting an attack of seven Yankee gunboat's and the land forces of sixty-eight, transports — from thirty to forty thousand men, who, having been just whipped out at Vicksburg, had come up the river in search of a force small enough to insure them a victory.
On Friday, Gen. Churchill, apprised of the advance of the enemy in large force, sent a dispatch for reinforcements.
The nearest point from which such and could be received was fifty miles distant. During that night the enemy landed their forces, and early on Saturday morning commended a most furious attack from both land and water.

Our men fought not only gallantly but desperately through all Saturday and Sunday, sometimes breasting back the auscultate from their earth-works with taste bayonets, and at other times encountering their dense masses in the open field.--No reinforce dents reached them from first to last.--Mc och's division and two regiments of cavalry, under command of Col. Geo. W. Carter, were on their way, but arrived only in season to lock the stable after the horse had been stolen.
It is gratifying to learn that Gen. Churchill, though carried off a prisoner, was not wounded in the fight.

It is reported and believed that the enemy intended to proceed immediately to an attack on Little Rock.
But the reduction of the Post was glory enough for one expedition, and they departed the next day as they came, leaving the guns unharmed as they found them, and the horses, mules and wagons to shift for themselves in the adjoining fields.
The capital, if taken, would afford them no advantage, as the archives are already removed therefrom, and the country is so far exhausted that the enemy could not subs for any length of time without importing supplies.

A detachment of the Yankee army, numbering about 4000 infantry and artillery, made a very unlooked for enter into Van Buren during the Christmas week.
Driving in end dispersing our pickets, they rushed through the town to the river, where they seized and scattered some commissary stoves.
They soon found occasion to leave, however, for, while in in medias res. an undiscovered battery on the opposite side of the river poured upon them a deadly fire, which induced them to doubt whether the place was altogether as safe as they had thought it. Those who escaped slept elsewhere, and have forgotten-to return since.

Arkansas possesses vast mineral wealth as well as an incomparable soil and climate for agricultural products, and immense resources for the purposes of war. It is out recently that much attention has been given to the development of the latter; yet we are informed that already great progress has been made in the martial arts, and the nearly all the ammunition used by our army there is supplied by the Confederate Ordnance Works at--,which are under the direction of a citizen of Petersburg.
Va. These works are doing for the war than all the other works of the kind beyond the Mississippi.

div4.head: The Situation of Affairs at Vicksburg.
div4.p: The correspondent of the Jackson Appeal, writing from Vicksburg on the 12th inst., says:

q.p:
From present appearances one is led to infer that the enemy near this city is about perfecting was for as offensive move, and that feature made eye. For several days past, his move have been indicating same attempt as throwing a force across the portion's to a point below, with a view of crossing the river to approach the city from below.
These movements have not yet been sufficiently developed to apprise us of their real purpose, and the programme may yet be changed, so that he will turn up in quite a different quarter from what is at present expected.

div4.p:
By deserters from the Yankee camp, who arrived here day before yesterday, we are informed that it was in contemplation by the enemy on Monday night last to run two or more of the gunboats by the batteries to get below town.
The affair was pretty generally known among the troops, several of whom managed to escape from the camp and crossed the river on a log. When they arrived here they imparted this information to the proper authorities upon which full and perfect arrangements were made on the part of our batteries to frustrate the success of such an attempt, if it should be made, it is believed that the fear of the batteries having knowledge of the affair, and that they had well prepared for it, kept them from undertaking the voyage.

Nothing definite could be made out of the work the enemy has been engaged at since Saturday up to Tuesday evening. By some it is argued that they are building a levee to keep from being washed out, while others insist that batteries are being erected by them with a view of shelling the town.
It appears almost certain now that a battery is being planted in the timber at a point a little below the city, so as to be within good range of our lower batteries.
A work of this kind of course would be intended more for the purpose of annoyance than resistance in an assault upon the city, while it might operate as an auxiliary to the fleet.

Several gunboats were in sight yesterday, and the whole fleet appeared to be remarkably quiet all day. No new move was apparent and everything looked very much like a weather bound fleet, unable to move either way. Upon what business the transports were engaged for the past few days in carrying troops up the river has not yet transpired; but the supposition that they were in search of higher land for a camping ground has as yet found no contradiction.
The only evidence of the presence of the vandals up the river, so far, was a conflagration on Sunday night, which reminded one very painfully of the fact that the incendiaries were engaged at their work.

A rumor prevails here that a large portion of the troops had been placed on transports and taken up to Greenville to attack a force of Confederates in that vicinity; but this report requires confirmation, and is not likely to be correct, as most of the boats have been in sight every day since Saturday.
The probabilities are that an effort will be made to get across the river by the troops stationed below the mouth of the canal, and that the ferry-beat and such of the captured steamers as they may have on hand will be used for this purpose.--If such a move was being made I would not blame the Yankee troops much for being disaffected at the prospect of being marched into a slaughter pen.

It will be nothing less than willful murder on the part of the Yankee General to attempt to land his troops anywhere an this side of the river.
The gallant Confederate soldiers are anxiously awaiting for him to do this, but it will be the most onboard of of human life, and the lower Mississippi will be red with the blood of Abolition victims, sacrificed to the rashness of incompetent and inhuman officers.
No doubt more gunboats will attempt to get below before this attempt is made, but it will avail him nothing and the greater the force he brings the greater will be the slaughter of his troops.
No wonder they are dissatisfied and escape from the camp at every favorable opportunity.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M.--Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore of the Presbyterian Church.
Mr. Clay, of Alabama, introduced a bill for the relief of Mrs. Laura Hasper, wife of Col. W. B. Harper, 1st regiment Arkansas cavalry.

Mr. Oer, of S. C., introduced a bill to vest in the Government, as part of its postage system, all rights of the American Telegraph Company, in the telegraph Lines in the Confederate States, and to provide for working the same.
Referred to the Committee on Postal Affairs.

Mr. Sparrow, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back the House bill to allow minors to hold commissions in the army, with the recommendation that it do not pass, further legislation on the subject being unnecessary in the opinion of the Committee.
The bill was placed on the calendar.
Mr. Hill, from the same committee, reported back House bill to authorize and regulate the impressments of public property, which, on his motion, was ordered to be printed, and placed on the calendar.
Mr. Hill also reported a bill to amend the act establishing military courts, which was ordered to be printed.
Mr. Davis, of N. C., submitted the following resolution:

Resolved, That the Committee on Military Affairs inquire into the propriety of so amending the existing laws, that private from any State enlisted in regiments from other States, may be transferred to regiments from their own State, without the consent of their company and regiment commanders.
The resolution was adopted.
The Senate resumed the consideration of the act defining who shall be exempt from military duty.
On motion of Mr. Caperton, of Va, the 4th section was amended by adding--

"The president of any canal company, secretary, chief clerks, chief-roll gatherer, and such mechanics in the permanent service of said company as the president under oath shall declare to be necessary."
Mr. Simme, of Ky, submitted an amendment prescribing as a condition of exemption, in various cases, the payment of a specified sum by the person to be exempt.
On motion of Mr. Clay, of Ala, the amendment was laid upon the table — yeas 14, nays 9.

Mr. Yancey moved to amend the fifth clause, exempting printers, etc, by adding "legislative and legal reporters" After much debate the amendment was rejected — ayes 10, noes 14.
[The vote was not recorded]

Mr. Henry, of Tenn, moved to amend the section relative to the exemption of overseers on plantations by striking out the provide requiring that the overseer to be exempted shall have been employed and acting as such previous to the 16th of April last.
The amendment was discussed by Mr. Hill, of Ga., Mr. Burnett, of Ky., and others, and was finally rejected — yeas 7, nays 17.

Mr. Maxwell, of Fla., moved to amend the same action by adding: "And provided further, that this clause shall not extend to any farm or plantation on which the negroes have been placed by division from any other farm or plantation since the 11th day of October, 1862."
This amendment was agreed to — yeas 23, nays 1--(Mr. Johnson, of Ark.)
The bill was then ordered to be engrossed and read a third time.
On motion of Mr. Sparrow it was ordered that the bill be printed.
The Senate then went into Executive session, and soon after adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock M., and was called to order by the Speaker.
The unfinished business — the bill to provide for the arrest of soldiers absent from their commands without leave, and providing compensation to their captors — was called up and considered.
The question recurred upon a motion to postpone the whole subject indefinitely, and on this motion the ayes and nose were called, and resulted — ayes 23 noes 48.

Aspirated debate sprang up upon the bill, which was participated in by Messrs. Perkins, Foote Miles, and Gertrell.
Without final action on the bill.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, of La, the House went into secret session on the Currency bill.

--The Senate met at noon, Mr. Johnson, President pro tempors in the Chair.
Prayer by the Rev. Dr. Moore, of the Presbyterian Church.

Bills and Petitions introduced--A bill to provide for the Trigonometrical and Geological Survey of the State.
A bill to incorporate the City insurance and Savings Society of the City of Petersburg, accompanied by the citizens of the same, praying for the granting of an act or similar act incorporating the same.
A bill to provide against forfeiture of compensation to fiduciaries in certain cases.

Resolutions.--By Mr. Marshall: Against preamble and resolutions concerning the inadequacy of the Virginia railroads, and recommending that the Confederate Government stock them with additional locomotives.
Read and laid over under the rules.
By Mr. Thomas: Recommending a still additional increase in the compensation of jailors now allowed them for keeping and supporting prisoners.
By Mr. Christian: Looking to the establishment of a Board to review and equalize assessments of property throughout the Commonwealth, and the principles of the law of 1867 on the subject.
Agreed to.

The joint Senate resolutions authorizing the Governor to appoint judicial and county officers in certain emergencies, and in relation to the suspension of the salary of Judge Pitts, of the 5th Circuit, were both taken up in succession.
The first was reported to the Committee for Courts of Justice, and the latter adopted and reported to the House.
Bills Passed.--A bill to allow the deputy of John M. Alderson, late Sheriff of Greenbrier county, deceased, to pay over certain militia fines an act to incorporate the Farmville Insurance Company.

The bill to provide representation in the General Assembly for certain counties and districts occupied by the public enemy coming up, Mr. Collier prevented he minority report of the committee as a substitute for the bill, and proceeded in some remarks thereon.
Mr. Coghill supported the bill as it came from the committee.
Pending the discussion, with Mr. Collier on the floor, on motion of Mr. Thomas, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock.
Senate bill allowing John Parsons, Sheriff of Lee county, further time to qualify and give the necessary bond of office, was read a second times committed to the Committee on Courts.
Mr. Anderson, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back Senate bill for the of the State Line to the Confederate Government with a recommendation that it pass.
On motion of Mr. Jones, the bill was laid on the table and ordered to be printed.

Mr. Harbour, from the Committee on Vinance reported a bill authorizing the Sheriff and Commissioner of the Revenue of the county of qualify and execute their official bond second time and ordered to its engrossment.

On motion of Mr. Baskerville, the rules were suspended, and the bill authorizing the establishment of a Military School as part of the instructions of Randolph Macon College was taken up, read a second time, and ordered to its engrossment.
On motion of Mr. Robertson the resolutions heretofore reported by him recommending an increased production of agricultural commodities, was taken up.
Mr. Hopkins withdrew his amendment.

The vote recurring on the second resolution, it was rejected — ayes 37, noes 51.
The vote was then taken upon the preamble, which was agreed to.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were introduced: By Mr. McConaid, of Hampshirs: Into the expediency of increasing the compensation allowed for the board, etc, of Confederate convicts from thirty cents per day to the sum now allowed jailors and others for other convicts.
By Mr. Amhers: Into the expediency of amending the act passed May 15th, 1862, empowering counties and corporations to issue small notes, so as to authorize them to establish agencies for their redemption in the cities of Richmond, Lynchburg, and Petersburg.
Mr. McCemant submitted the following resolution, which was agreed to:

Resolved. That the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to inquire into and to report to this House the number of beef castle killed and salted at Saltville for the use of the State troops, the number of pounds salted who was the Commissary or agent employed in that business, whether any, and if any how much thereof, is spoiled and unfit for use, the amount of loss the State has sustained thereby; and that the committee have power to send for persons and papers.
On motion of Mr. Barbour the order of the day — the Tax bill — was taken up and discussed till the hour of adjournment.

div3.head: The next Yankee House of Representatives.
div3.p: --The Cincinnati Enquirer says the next Lincoln House of Representatives stands at present as follows:

Democrats, 74½ Abolitionists, 77.
Right States, to wit, Vermont, Rhods Island, Connecticut, New Hampshire, California, Kentucky, Maryland, and Western Virginia, have yet to elect, and the result is estimated as follows: Democrat, 21; Abolitionists 10.
This will give a total of Democrats 95; Abolitionists, 87.

The Enquirer then concludes that the Abolitionists are will be in a minority of eight, unless they can feist upon the House bogus members from the seceded States.
A sharp contest will come up undoubtedly upon the Missouri members when they present their certificates.
The Democrats and Conservatives will, in the end, probably control the House.
The seat of one of the Abolitionists from Iowa's contested.
So are the seats of two from Pennsylvania.

div3.head: What Morgan has done.
div3.p: --Col. R. M. Geno, of Texas, gives the Vicksburg Whig the following statistics of Morgan's career:

"He has fought 53 battles, killed 130 Yankees, wounded 372, captured 4,283 and destroyed property to the amount of $15,163,000, all with a force of 800 and with very small loss.
In his late affair at Hartsville, the first time he commanded a brigade, he killed 10 wounded 18 captured 1,350, took six pieces of artillery, and carried away or destroyed $65,000 worth of property.

div3.head: Acquitted.
div3.p:
--The examination of Capt. James W. Henley of Amberst who shot and killed Robt. A. Staples, at Farmville, Va, on the 27th of Jan., commenced before the county court of Prince Edward on Monday, and was concluded on Wednesday last.
The accused plead in defence of the killing the seduction of his wife by the deceased while he was absent in the service of his country.
The evidence fully sustained the plea, and the Court unanimously decided, that the homicide was justifiable, and discharged the accused.
They declined to hear any argument in the case, but acquitted the prisoner solely on the merits of the testimony.

div3.head: Southern Funds.
div3.p: --On the 14th inst. $10,000 in bills on solvent Georgia, South Carolina, Alabama, &c. banks sold in Memphis at 95 Another lot of $1,000 went off at 97
Hon. Ed. Shett, a distinguished citizen of South Carolina, died in Spartausburg, S. C.; last week.
Capt. Wm. McBlair, C. S. M., died in Savannah, Ga., on the 16th inst.
City Council A special meeting of the City Council was held yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

A report was received from the Committee on Light, through Mr. Hill recommending that the price of gas be increased to six dollars per thousand feet on the quarterly bills to be made out on the 1st of May next and on all other bills for the 1st of April next.
This was agreed to. The committee further recommend the following increase of salaries of the officers of the Gas Works, as follows: Superintendent, $2,500; Inspector, $1,800 Assistant Inspector, $1,500. This portion of the report was laid upon the table.
Mr. Grattan, from the special committee on the City Aims House, made a report and submitted the following, which was adopted:

It having been represented to the Council that it is of great importance to the Confederate authorities that they should be permitted to retain the use of the building erected by the Council as an aims house, as a hospital for sick and wounded soldiers of the Confederate army: Therefore.

Resolved, That the Confederate authorities be authorizes to occupy the said building for the purposes aforesaid at a rent of seven thousand dollars per annum, commencing on the 1st day of January, 1863 and payable quarterly: Provided that the said building and no part thereof, shall be used as a hospital for persons suffering from small pox or varioloid diseases.
The following resolutions, offered respectively by Messrs Burr and Wynne, were agreed to:

Resolved, That a committee of three, of whom the President of the Council that be one, be appointed to remonstrate against the passage of the bill now before our Legislature, which proposes to give unlimited and uncontrolled use of the streets of the city to the railroad companies.

Resolved, That the representatives of this city in the Legislature be, and they are hereby, requested to oppose the bill now before that body, authorizing the connecting of the different railroads terminating in this city, so far as it gives the companies authority to make these connections without consulting the city authorities.

Mr. Grattan submitted two curlinesses with the following titles, which under a suspension of the rules, were considered and passed: To amend the ordinance concerning the powers and duties of the City Assessor.
To amend the ordinance directing the manner of receiving and disbursing money at the City Treasury and prescribing the duties of the Auditor and Chamberlin.

Mr. Grattan, from the Committee on Finance, submitted a report showing the receipts and disbursements of the city for the eleven months ending the 1st of February, and estimates of the receipts and disbursements of the next fiscal year.
It appears that the whole amount paid into the Treasury during the eleven months, including the amount on hand at the of the year, was $1,040, 153, 72; the whole amount of disbursements was $977,762.58; leaving in the Treasury on the 1st of February. $62,424. Taking into consideration the operations of the present month, it is estimated that there will be left in the Treasury as the commencement of the next fiscal year, $33,000. After giving the Auditor's estimate of the receipts and disbursements for the next fiscal year, the report closes as follows:

"Under all the circumstances that surround us it certainly is not prudent to estimate our expenditures for the next year at a less sum than they have been in the present; and to meet these expenditures the Council must either raise the taxes or go in debt for them.
This certainly is not a time to do this last.
We see every private debtor in the country who intends ever to pay his debts is doing it now, and it is in the present state of the current by and abundance of money, highly inexpedient to contract a debt which must be paid under a very different state of things.
The Committee are of opinion that an increased tax at present, when rents are fourfold and profits of capital are even greater, is the proper mode of meeting the necessary expenditures of the city.
They have therefore, reported an ordinance in accordance with the opinion herein expressed."
The ordinances "imposing taxes for the support of the city government," was taken up, and was under consideration at a late hour with a probability of its passage.

div3.head: The railroads.
div3.p:
--The upward bound mail train of the Central road was detained several hours, yesterday, by the fore wheels of the engine running off the track when about two hundred yards from Gordonsville.
The engine of another train, bound down, ran off just beyond Gordonsville.
The down train was several hours behind last night, in consequence of these accidents.

The Fredericksburg train, due Sunday evening, got in about one o'clock yesterday, and reported the track clear.
A detention of the accommodation train from Petersburg was caused by a locomotive getting off the track at the bridge, but no damage was done.

div3.head: Death of a Yankee officer.
div3.p:
--Captain John Ayres, of company H, 16th Maine regiment, who was wounded and taken prisoner by our forces at the battle of Fredericksburg, died on yesterday at the hospital of the Libby prison.
Every care and attention was bestowed on him during his illness.

div3.head: Arrest of Robbers.
div3.p:
--Four young men balling from Richmond, and who gave their names as Peter Kiny, Wm. H. Burne, Chas Comstock, and James Hanley, were arrested in Petersburg on Saturday last on the charge of being engaged in the resent heavy robberies committed in this city and Petersburg.
These four men left here on Saturday morning, and on the same title was a Petersburg merchant, who had sustained a loss of one or more valuable pieces of cloth, and who recognized there buries as being the same who had visited his store on the day of his loss.
He made known the fact of their presence to other merchants of that city, and a plan was determined upon for their detection, which proved successful.
Goods were displayed as usual at the windows and doors of the stores, and in a little while the thieves stopped in front of one of them, and after taking their departure the merchant on examination found a piece of calico had been taken.
The thieves were closely watched, and an officer, accompanied by a gentleman who could recognize them, was put upon their trail, and all four were arrested--one at an eating-house in the town, and the other three near the Richmond Depot.
Upon one of them was found the missing piece of calico.
Their main depot of operations is believed to be in this city.
When confronted with each other in jail they positively denied all knowledge of one another.
Their case was to come up before the Mayor of Petersburg yesterday morning.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--Five Union men were brought to the military prison of the Eastern district, yesterday morning, from Saulsbury, N. C. Benji Thicker, who was lodged in the above prison some months ago for forging a sick ferlcngu, died in the hospital of the prison yesterday.
Two Yankee deserters were lodged in the Libby prison yesterday.
At the same date there were confined there 67 prisoners of war, including 25 or more Yankee officers; 119 citizen prisoners, 63 Yankee deserters, and 22 negroes.

div3.head: Major's Court.
div3.p:
--Two pugnacious individuals, arrested for fighting in the theatre on Saturday night, were arraigned yesterday and bound over to keep the peace.
A Confederate Lieutenant, charged with stealing a horse from John Wilder Atkinson, proved his innocence of the crime, and was released from custody.
A negro map, arrested for stealing a piece of cloth, was discharged, but the cloth was retained, and can be had by the owner on application, with proof, at the Mayor's office.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p:
--The city police made one arrest yesterday.
A man giving the name of Wm. M Naryred was looked up in the cage for drawing a bowie-knife on Wm. B. Lyons and breaking up some articles of household-ware belonging to the said Lyons.
It is almost unnecessary today that Naryred was very drunk when he committed this breath of the peace.

div3.head: Nothing to eat.
div3.p:
--If the state of supplies was to continue for a few days like that of yesterday morning, at the Second Market, our inhabitants would inevitably experience the horrors of starvation.
There were two hucksters only in the vegetable department, with a few eggs, turkeys, sweet potato as and pees and one old woman selling hominy, all demanding marvellous prices.
The country carts, which usually contribute a portion of the supplies, were detained at home by the snow.
At the First Market affairs were pretty much in the same condition.

div3.head: Sleighing
div3.p: --Although the sun's rays caused a rapid dissolution of the snow yesterday, there were many persons willing to pay ten dollars an hour for the use of a sleigh, so determined were they to have one ride this season.

div3.head: The Fredericksburg sufferers.
div3.p: --The Council of the city of Richmond, it is stated, propose to appropriate ten thousand dollars for the benefit of the Fredericksburg sufferers.

div3.head: Small Fox.
div3.p:
--This disease is rapidly abating.
A few days since there were but thirteen patients in the City hospital.

div3.head: A French steamer ashore.
div3.p:
--The French war steamer Renaudini; while trying to enter the harbor this morning, ran ashore off Sullivan's Island.
The British steamer Petrel and French steamer Milan have been trying all day to get her off, but so far unsuccessful.

div3.head:
Hdqrs Mallory Troop,
Richmond, February 20th, 1863
div3.p:
A few more Recruit are wanted to fill up my company of Cavalry, to serve at Gen. Les's body Guard.
Horses, equipment, a complete outfit, and $50 bounty, furnished to each recruit. --These wishing to join this corps will report to me at Mr. Thos T Johnson's office, opposite Columbian Hotel, or to Lieut David Johnson, at Coup Lac , by the 5th of March as no recruits will be received after that time.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Earn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 8 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust dead.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 47, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which al money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be rent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed to an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and sealed with wax, writing the subscribers name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: The currency — Taxation.
div3.p:
The Congress now in session have had under consideration many schemes for improving the currency.
These generally look for the diminution of the amount of paper afloat by a forced conversion of notes into Confederate bonds.
None of them as far as we know anything of them, bear the impress of practicability or even justness.--They are better calculated to depreciate the currency than any other cause we are aware of. Indeed, these which propose that all notes of certain issues not presented for conversion into bonds by a certain date shall not be converted into bonds at the rate of interest (eight per cent.,) to which they are entitled by the promise on their face, make a proposition plainly fraudulent.

But the Congress should, before it runs into these impracticable schemes for retiring the currency, discharge a solemn obligation to the country by passing a tax bill.
This act, which is due to the Government and the cause, would do something towards bettering the credit of the Government paper, and would assist in a measure in diminishing its amount.
The people, next to fighting and perilling their lives for their country, can give no such proof of confidence in their Government and determination to sustain it as by paying taxes.
In the estimation of the world, nothing can give so much confidence in the solvency of a Government as the ability and willingness of the people who live under it to pay taxes for its support.

We believe the people of the Southern Confederacy are ready to give this proof of their fidelity to the Government of their choice, and their representatives will fall of their public duty and prove recreant to the constituent will if they do not pass a liberal and equitable tax bill for the support of Government.
It is a measure indispensable at this time.
It will do more than anything else to improve the credit of the Government, and if it is omitted that credit must be seriously diminished, and both Government and people be more and more involved in the dreaded consequences of a depreciated paper currency.

div3.head: The winter campaign.
div3.p:
The winter months will be over on next Saturday, although we may look for much winter weather during the month of March.
The enemy at the beginning of the season boasted largely of what they intended to do before it was over.
Their million of men were to restore the fortunes of Yankeedom, and to wipe out by their grand achievements all the disasters of the preceding summer and fall.
They believed that the scenes of the former winter could be repeated — that the rise of the Western waters would give full play to their gunboats, and that conquests like those of Fort Donelson, Island No.10, and Memphis, would follow fast upon the heels of each other, until all Yankeedom should become unable to shout "victory" from sheer hoarseness and exhaustion.
In the South, they supposed that the tragedy of Roanoke Island was to be repeated on a huge scale, with a prodigiously increased number of actors.
They did not take into consideration the very great difference between the state of the Confederacy ago and its state at the present moment.
At that time supine inertness, misplaced confidence, and a general belief that the war was soon to be closed by foreign intervention, had enfeebled the whole people, and prepared the way for unlimited disaster.
The volunteer system had brought its proper fruits, in leaving us almost without an army.
Confusion reigned in the War office, and Congress was too much afraid of the "dear people" to take any steps for the salvation of the public cause.
The times are very different now. We have that has never fought without conquering — that has chiefs in whom it relies to lead it to — victory whenever the long roll-may be beaten for a rally to arms — that will follow those chiefs whenever they point out the way. It has several others of material equally good, that want only the same experience to be quite equal in every respect.
We have, above all, a Secretary at the head of the War Department who knows what he is about, who does his own duty and makes others attend to theirs.
We have a conscription which has already saved the country once, and has proved its most powerful bulwark ever since.

Thus far the winter campaign of the Yankees has been a failure.
In Virginia and Tennessee it has been a most disastrous failure.
To undertake a winter campaign at all, in fact, without securing enormous advantages, is of itself a failure.
Even great victories scarcely counterbalance the enormous evils which are its inseparable attendant, and it is never undertaken by able chiefs without the prospect of some advantage sufficient of itself to compensate the inevitable loss.
Such an advantage the Yankees have not secured.
On the contrary, they have been defeated with great slaughter at Fredericksburg — have fought a bloody battle and met with a bloody repulse at Murfreesboro', and have been driven back with shame at Vicksburg.
Their troops have become demoralized to an extent unknown in war since the Russian campaign, by their struggle with the weather and the hardships inseparable from campaigning in this season, and have deserted and died by thousands.
Unless they can succeed at Charleston, Savannah, and Vicksburg — all three places — they will have gained nothing whatever to compensate them for the losses and hardships which they have endured.
And we can see no prospect whatever of their succeeding at either of them.
It would have been wiser in Lincoln to have taken a lesson from nature, and not to have recommended the war until the gave the signal for the trees to bud and the birds to fly abroad.

If we shall be able to retain the several cities now threatened our gain will have been equal to a dozen pitched battles fought and won. We shall open the campaign in the spring with renewed life and the prestiges of certain success.
We have no means of obtaining a right of things behind the curtain; but, to an outsider, the prospect seems exceedingly fair.
We have already shown our enemy that numbers do not always prevail, and if taking the hint, he shall reduce his, we shall then beat him to death.

div3.head:
Depot army Committee Y. M. C. A.
and Ladies' soldiers' aid Society,
Richmond, Feb. 22d, 1863.
div3.p:
The citizens of Richmond are requested to send to our Depot, corner of Bank and 10th streets, any articles of Clothing or Furniture which can be spared, however plain, for the use of soldiers' wives and children who have been placed under our charge.
Contributions for this object, thankfully received.

div4.p:
On Tuesday, the 10th inst., by the Rev. Mr. Grittfith at Glenwood, N. C. Mr. Joseph Williams and Miss M. Lou.
Glen, all of Yadkin county, N. C. *
On the 13th February, 1863, Mr. H S McPHERSON, of Georgetown, D C, and Miss M may Trent, of Farmville, Va.
Baltimore and Washington City papers please copy. *

On the morning of Monday, the 23d inst, at the residence of her mother.
Mary Ann, the wife of John A. Motherland, after a brief but painful illness, in the 27th, year of her age.
Ever an affectionate, dutiful child; a devoted wife and mother; a loving sister and relative; a sincere and kind friend, she leaves all to mourn their irreparable loss on earth.

Thou hast lard Thy hand heavily upon them!--Death has been in their midst and has taken one who held a large place in their affections.
The light that burned so pleasantly on the altar of their hopes has gone out in the darkness and coldness of the grave.
The voice that made music into their hearts has fallen into silence; and the eyes that blamed love upon them are closed forever.
Desolation and grief have come into the place of gladness and rejoicing.
O, thou God of consolation, have mercy upon them; comfort them in their distress.
Renew to them the sweet assurance that death has no power over the strength and tenderness of human love; that all that was good and true and beautiful in their beloved one still lives, and will forever live, in Thy-glorious presence.
The friends of the family are invited to attend her burial from her mother's residence, on Main street, at 11 o'clock A. M. this day.
Greenville (S. C.) papers please copy. *

On Monday morning Feb'y 23d, at half past 10 o'clock, after a short illness, Mrs. Hester, wife of Edwin E Cordon, in the 27th year of her age, leaving a husband and two small children to mourn their irreparable loss.
Her funeral will take place this morning, at 10½ o'clock, from the residence of her husband, on Venable street. *
On Monday morning, at half past 10 o'clock, Kate Ella, only daughter of Wm H and Casanna Blake, aged 3 months and 12 days.

lg.l: Lay her gently in the coffin,
Fold her arms across her breast;
Wrap the cold shroud around her,
Our little Katio's gone to rest.
Oh! my heart is sad and lonely,
As I weep above thy bed;
And my home is lone and dreary,

div4.p: Chattanoga papers please copy. *
In Louisa county, Va., on the 18th inst, Richard M. second son of R E Hugison, aged 3 years.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, on the 6th of February at Oakland, in Hanover county, Frances Suselia Matthews, in the 39th year of her age.

Amid death's gathering gloom she knew no fear; calm, quiet and resigned, after a painful and lingering disease, she yielded her spirit to the God who gave.
Death came like a peaceful slumber, and her weary eyes looked their last on a smiling world.
To all who mourn their loss there is a sweet comfort in the divine assurance that, though gone before, she is not lost to them.
Purified by heavenly love, her gentle spirit awaits them in that pure home above, where the reunion will be for eternity.
Patient and forbearing, she bore her affliction with most matchless resignation — she endured the cross and won the crown. *

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p: --A good Cook and Laundress, with a likely mulatto female child, six years old.

Also, for hire, from the 1st of March, a first-rate Cook and Laundress, with three children.
Apply to Mrs. Judge Clopton, on Franklin st., between 3d and 4th.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--For the balance of the year, two negro Women, who can cook, wash, and iron.
Apply at Thos Jones's, No. 8 Main st.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman suitable for a wet nurse.
She is a good seamstress washer and ironer.
Apply at Mrs. Pendleton's on Cary street, between 3d and 4th.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman, of excellent character, as Cook in a private family.
She is without encumbrance.
Also, a Girl, for Dining-room Servant or Nurse, who is honest and can be recommended in every respect.
Call on Grace st, two doors above Adams.

div3.head:
Ordnance Dep't of Va.,
Richmond, Feb'y 20, 1863.
div3.p: Second Class Militia--Officers of the Second Class Militia to whom Arms have been issued for their companies by this Department are hereby required to delivery the same to me at the Virginia Armory, corner of 7th and Cary sts, with as little delay as possible.
div3.closer:
By order:
P. C. Coghlaw, Captain,
Ordnance Dep't of Va. fe 21--ts

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To take the place of a conscript.
For one over 45 years of age, and well recommended, a good price will be paid.
Apply at Camp Lee to-day.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in a good company.
Call at E H Stokes to-day, by 10 o'clock.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute, to go in the army for the war. For one that can come well recommended a liberal price will be paid.--None need apply under 45.
Call as the office of W & G Gwathrey, above the Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For one that will suit a fair price will be paid.
Apply at once to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Apply at Mrs. Barres's second door from St. Paul's Church, above the Monument Hotel, on Grace st.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A reliable man. A satisfactory price will be paid.
Apply to it H Dibrell, Shockoe Slip.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To buy a handsome set of Rosewood or Mahogany Chamber Furniture.
A good price will be paid for the same if application is made immediately.
No one need call unless it is handsome and modern.
Call at 98 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two Servants to go to the army, slave or free.
Good wages paid.--Apply immediately to the undersigned, at Camp Lee.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young man not subject to the conscription act wishes a Situation in some respectable mercantile house; has had some experience in business, and can give the best city references.
Address "J S C," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A good Dwelling-House, on Shockoe or Church Hill, with six or eight rooms and out building, for which a fair will be paid per annuls, or a liberal price for the foe simple provided possession can be obtained within the next thirty days. Address "Box No. 523, Richmond Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young Man to aid in recruiting a company in a desirable branch of the service, for a Lieutenancy.
Address "Captain." Dispatch Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Fifty men for the "Provost Marshal's Guard at Lynchburg.
Bounty $50. For particulars apply to.
div3.closer:
D M Snovell,
Corner of 14th and Main sts. fe 24--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Situation, by a young man who has been regularly discharged from the army.
Would be pleased to get a situation as Clerk in some house.
Good references given.
Address "Alfred," at the Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Man to work on the Batteries.
I will pay $150 for sixty days in addition to the Government pay. Apply at the Dispatch office this day.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Cook, Warsher, and Cleaner, without encumbrance.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Isaac Scheiver, Franklin st,
Opposite the Verities. fe 24--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A large size, Fire and Hurglar proof says, for which a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to Hawis Hyman, 93 Sain st.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--We wish to employ a first-rate Sa M Man and Clerk.
For such a will pay a good price.

div3.head: Wanted.--Flax Seed
div3.p: --I will pay the highest cash price for Flak Seed in any quantity.
div3.closer:
W L Montangue,
Corner Bank and 12th sts. fe 24--4t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A House, either furnished or unfurnished, or two rooms, in a central partition, of the city for a small family.
Address. "A H" Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Substitute of good character.
The highest price will be paid.--Apply to No. 17 main st.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A good middle-aged colored Murse.
Apply to
Robinson, Adams & Co.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent, by a gentleman, a well furnished Chamber, or Parlor and Chamber, without board.
First floor preferred.
Address "X. Y. Z. Y," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To hire for sixty days, a Hand to work on the Enter of. A very liberal price will be given.
Apply to Mr. M. D Eacho,

div3.head: Three hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $300 in cash to any one who will arrest Michael Rodney, who deserted from my company last night after having regularly entered as a substitute three days before.
He is a short, thick-built Irishman and were, when he left, a pair of blue Yankee pants, citizen's boat, and a black wool hat, badly worn; he is 46 or 47 years old and has generally worked on a Broad he once lived in Alexandria; has recently lived in Richmond, where it is said he has a wife and two children.
The above reward will be paid to any one who will lodge him in tle Thunder or any other prison, and notice me of the same or for his head, should be resist arrest.
div3.closer:
Wm T. Nicholson,
Capt. comd'g co. E, 37th N. C. Reg't.
Dane's Brigade, A. P. Hill's Div.
February 20th, 1863. fe 24--2w

div3.head: Ninety dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from Co. C. 53d Va. Reg't.--
Isaac King, complexion dark, hair dark, eyes blue, height 5 feet 7 inches, slight scar on the left check.

George Ellis, age 46 years, complexion dark, hair dark and slightly gray, eyes blue, height 5 feet 4½ inches, bottom front teeth large and irregular; supposed to be lurking about Chesterfield Coal Pits.
The above reward will be paid for their delivery at Castle Thunder, or $45 for either.

div3.head: Camp Lee, Feb. 20, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted — From Camp Lee, on or about the 8th February, James Young a fisherman by wade and substitute for D. H. White, Culpaper county.
Said Young is 47 years old, dark hair, dark eyes, dark complexion, and 5 feet 6 inches high.
A reward of $20 will be given for his delivery to Capt. Booker, at Castle Thunder.

closer.signed: Lt. com'dg co. F. 21st Va. Reg't.

div3.head: Camp Lee, Feb'y 20, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted — From Camp Lee on or about the 8th of February, H. A. Phillips, a farmer by trade.
Said H. A. Phillips is 37 years of age; blue eyes; dark hair; dark complexion, and 5 feet 10½ inches high.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his delivery to Capt. Hooker, at Castle Thunder.

closer.signed: Wm. G. Gray, Lt. comd'g com'y F.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--From Camp Lee, on or about the 17th of February, John Coleman, a substitute, and an Irishman by birth.
Said John Coleman is 47 years of age 5 feet 8 inches high, blue eyes dark hair, and dark complexion.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his delivery to Capt. Hooker, Castle Thunder.
div3.closer:
Wm. G. Gray.
Lieut. Com'g Co. F. 21st Va. Reg't.
Camp Lee, Feb. 20, 1863. fe 21--eod3t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $100 for the arrest and judgment in a safe jail of my man George if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on the 14th inst. about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about 5 feet high, 23 years old, brown color, and weighs about 190 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock cost, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.

div3.head:
Freight office E. & D. R. E.
Richmond, Feb. 10, 1863.
div3.p:
Special Notice.--Taken up at the depot of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, this day, a small negro boy, named John, who says he belongs to a Mr. Peter Burnley, from the country. --Said boy is about eight years old, and of a gingerbread complexion.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges and take him away.

closer.signed: F. S. Ween, E. & D. E. R.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, last spring, Albert, about 16 years of age, very black, open countenance and lips when speaking.
He is supposed to be employed by some office in General Lee's army.
I will give the above reward for his arrest and return to me, or confinement in jail so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
Jno. D. Q. Lambles,
Corner Main and Foothee sts. fe 20--eod6t*
